Tl-95, T2-95, T3-95, T4-95.Thursday,2 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1487 Thursday, 2 March 1995 Employment, Education and Training Committee Report on violence in Australian schools Debate resumed from 7 December 1994, on motion by Mr Beazley: That the House take note of the paper. the first response to the government's response to a report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Sticks and stones, which was a report on violence in Australian schools. It is interesting when debating in this chamber that, unlike the major chamber of the House of Representatives, the enemy faces each other eyeball to eyeball across the chamber. This report of the committee, which is an all-party committee of this House, was a unanimous report. I learned a number of major things in participating in this inquiry. The first thing that I learned which was most significant is that teachers believe that those who commit physical violence generally lack self-esteem. The second thing that I learned which I believe is of significance is that over the past two decades, as a permissive society has developed, we have increasingly given children their rights, but, in the absence of parental discipline and the structures of dos and don'ts, children have been left to flounder, without direction and experience in how to take responsibility for their own actions and deal responsibly with their peers and with the broader community. That is a substantive problem. The third major thing that I learned during the inquiry was that there are models of school practice which generally exhibit strong leadership and a whole school approach, creating a culture of caring that negates both violence and bullying. In that respect, I discussed the experiences of Mayfield Primary School in Launceston. The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training( Mr Free) has largely accepted the findings of our report. I would now like to deal with some of the more major recommendations. The minister has said in his report that he believes that a series of forums on violence in schools held in each state and territory would be a very useful process for compiling the good practice that is occurring in schools around Australia. I have no major philosophical disagreement with the minister about holding forums, but it seems to me, in a practical sense, that we would be doing an awful lot of spinning wheels, bringing together a lot of people for lots of discussions, which would simply parallel other meetings and other discussions. The committee mentality and structure carries on. I would have much preferred that the minister had accepted our recommendations in principle and then an expert go out and do some fact finding. Let us fund an expert to do some fact finding and report on the primary schools of Australia: to report on good practice, particularly where their practice has acted to almost totally eliminate the concept of bullying; to report on practices which have been successful in integrating strong approaches at dealing

speaker: Mr Charles (La Trobe) (10.01 A.m.)
theText: I am delighted to have the opportunity to makeMC 1488 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 March 1995 with problems of illiteracy, particularly in the early years of primary school; and to disseminate that information widely to primary and secondary schools throughout Australia. An expert charged with this responsibility could call for submissions from schools that had demonstrated exemplary practice. That person could then collate the information and make it available. This would be more useful than holding a series of talkfests. The minister dealt firstly with our recommendation that the ministers of the Commonwealth, states and territories fund the evaluation of successful approaches adopted by schools. It was his response to hold a series of forums, which I have dealt with. However, he did go on in his recommendation and canvass the possibility that the Commonwealth would investigate establishing, in cooperation with the state and territory governments, a best practice award for schools that display leadership in this field. I commend the minister for that response; I think that will be really useful. One of the things that we have learned through this committee, in travelling around the country, is that the apprenticeship awards-the awards that deal with excellence in the international skills olympics-have been a tremendous boost to T AFE colleges and to the apprenticeship systems around the country. Many of those young people who have participated in the international skills olympics have gone on to find rewarding, responsible and satisfying jobs very early in their careers. No doubt their participation in those skills olympics has enhanced their career prospects. They provide an example for their peers who are studying in the skills field. I compliment the minister on his suggestion for a best practice award and would suggest that that is appropriate. We recommended that the minister, in consultation with the states, finance the development of a national school violence data collection system. The minister has in total agreed with us. I thank the minister. The minister said that the Commonwealth will refer this recommendation to the School Statistics Taskforce of the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs and that he would ask the task force to examine how more extensive national data on the issue can be obtained and how the data could be used for the development of performance indicators on school violence. That is a very good initiative. There is no way the Commonwealth could now impose its will or the committee's will on the states, and nor should it. This is a complex area and involves issues such as: the definition of violence-and levels of violence; the issue of bullying and where it fits in those definitions; and how we report on those issues. It does need to be decided by consensus. All the states need to agree finally on a formula of definition so that the data collection can recommence throughout the country in an identical manner, so at the end of the day we have some numbers that are of use to us. This committee was told anecdotally that physical violence was on the wane and that there was less physical violence in schools in Australia today than 30 or 40 years ago. That is a very positive outcome, but we are not sure if that is true. The problem ithere is no data to back up the observations. We really need a comprehensive but simple data collection system that will give us some numbers and allow people to take actions based on the findings. For example, if some mechanisms in some states are working and producing outcomes which are better than the models in other states, certainly it would behove the states who are having poor results to take cognisance of the fact that they have colleagues in other places who seem to be doing it better, and perhaps they should shift their practices. This data collection issue is really quite important. Thursday, 2 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1489 Another of our recommendations was that the minister discuss with the state and territory ministers the need for early intervention strategies to address violent and anti-social behaviour in students. In part,the minister's response said that the Commonwealth government endorses the committee's finding that preventative action in the early years of schoo ling is far more likely to prove effective than any piecemeal or remedial solutions focused on students in older age groups. I thank the minister for that. We are convinced that is right. If we get it right early, the chances are that behaviour will be vastly improved in the later years of schooling as well. However, we did receive some evidence that some young people who demonstrate no tendencies to violence or bullying in primary school seem to go a bit haywire under some peer pressure or community or social mores when they reach their teens, and there have to be different mechanisms to deal with that. The minister talked about the gender and violence project, developing a video on violence for use in primary schools, but this issue is not just a gender issue. It is not just that little boys beat up on little girls or big boys beat up on big girls; in fact there was some anecdotal evidence that young girls are increasingly resorting to verbal bullying themselves, and that is quite worrying for many of our educators. I am not sure that this is totally a gender issue. Certainly, the physical violence occurs largely between young males-Qr young males physically violating young girls-but the bullying aspect seems to be more evenly balanced and the fact that there seems to be some increasing physical violence amongst young girls was worrying to the committee. One of our recommendations was an examination of the effects of television, video, film and video games on the learning outcomes and behaviour of Australian children. The minister agrees with our concern that media and entertainment may have an effect on violence and behaviour of children, not only in the school setting but in the broader community. The minister says that the communications and the arts portfolio already makes a significant contribution to safeguarding the well-being of children in relation to media content. I think I would have to question the minister's statement. I am not totally convinced that our classification mechanisms do work. When I turn on my television, which is rare I must admit, there certainly are days when no matter what channel I switch to there is nothing but violence on show. I am not convinced that that is for the betterment of our young people. I note that the Prime Minister( Mr Keating) has recently called for the examination of the possibility of a fourth free to air television channel, largely dedicated to families and children. I suppose that is worth exploring, although I am not sure that there is enough market and I think that market research would have to be done. I can tell you that many families would support a reduction in the amount of violence that we see on free to air television in Australia. Perhaps pay TV will help solve part of this problem. One can only hope, but we will never know until we get there and unfortunately we are a bit slow in that regard. But, in discussing our recommendation on the International Year of the Family, the minister went on to compliment the government for supporting the parents' role in school education by providing $555,000 to the parents association over three years, and that is in rather dramatic conflict with· the donation of the Minister for Health (Dr Lawrence) of a quarter of million dollars in one shot to the December issue of Cleo, which goes out, unfortunately, to 13to 18-year-old females, which I believe was inappropriate in all the circumstances, dealing with the issues that we are dealing with here. MC 1490 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 March 1995 Ms HENZELL (Capricornia) (10.16 a.m.)-I am very pleased to have the opportunity to speak on the government's response to the report Sticks and stones, a report on violence in Australian schools by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. I acknowledge the contribution by the chair of that committee, the member for Forde (Ms Crawford),and the previous speaker, the member for La Trobe( Mr Charles), who was the deputy chair of that committee. This is an issue of very considerable concern to parents. In my previous professional experience I had some involvement in counselling victims of violence in schools, and also as a parent, as I charted my own daughter's journey through primary and secondary education, I have been a concerned consumer in this area. It is very pleasing to note the general support of the government for the committee's report and a number of initiatives that the government is taking on board in response to this report. The response has actually been presented very quickly, in my view. I want to make some comments about the general area. I certainly think there is a need for further research but also, as the government indicates; it is prepared to participate in the collection of data and the dissemination of that data to schools, particularly on the incidence as well as benchmarks and best practice options that the committee was able to pick up during the course of its inquiry. One area that I have some concern about is the evidence on the causal relationship between violence and self-esteem of the perpetrators and the victims. I believe there does need to be much more research into what determines why some children choose to bully. However, I acknowledge that it is not simply an individual psychological problem but that we have to look at a number of factors that cause violence in schools. I note the committee's comments on page 11, paragraph 2.3: This committee agrees with the view that violence does not arise from a single cause. In this, it agrees with the national committee on violence. It says: Evidence suggested the following influences in the school context: the family; cultural factors, especially social and economic inequality; media influences; and aspects of the school environment. I believe that not only a whole of school approach is required to combat violence but a whole of community approach, and it does mean getting parents involved and out of school factors as well as media, and in particular the social structure of the school system. One of the initiatives that I as a parent was involved with in the primary school that my children attended was the development of a human relationships education program. This whole issue had a very long gestation and parents fought for it in the dark days of conservative rule in Queensland. When the green light was given for the development of human relationships education, a great deal was done by the Queensland education department to foster community involvement. There were a number of participants in my small mining community. What was interesting, I have to say, was that a minority group which represented-if one would describe it as such a 'fundamentalist Christian' position had a very narrow view of what should constitute a human relationships education. I would have to summarise it as a 'God, queen, country and the Bible' type of approach, with very limited opportunities to present the plurality of society. However, the consultation, with the support of the Queensland Department of Education, went ahead, and we developed a very positive program for our school community. Thursday, 2 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1491 One of the issues that I believe is very important is the recognition of the power structures within a school. That very much involves having the adults in the school system be aware of the sort of power that they have, and of when the system can get into the abuse of power. It has been my experience, in observing children, that they have a very strong sense of social justice and are very aware when teachers override what could be seen as fair play or a fair and reasonable outcome. It is very important that teachers be aware of that when they use their power as adults: their power to be more articulate and more analytical, and to put students down. So, when we look at the structures that need to be in place to provide a really caring school, based on mutual respect, all relationships need to be taken into consideration. One of the very important findings of the committee is in relation to the importance of early intervention. I quote from page 8 of the introduction. It says: The majority of evidence suggests that inappropriate behaviours are identifiably in children as early as pre-school and kindergarten. Changing a child's behaviour patterns after the age of eight requires significantly more resourcing, with reduced changes of success, than if the problem was addressed in the earliest schooling years. Indeed, I can remember observing a number of children who went right through kindergarten, preschool and grades one and two with my daughters. It was very clear that they had already embarked upon a career that would ultimately isolate them and nominate them as troublemakers and difficult children. I then saw the responses that were used-being, at that time, very traditional school discipline responses-having absolutely no success at all. At that stage, I was not practising professionally, but I was bringing my professional eye to my observations. Living in a small community, I could also see the complementary family problems that were contributing to the way these children would present at school. I was feeling very concerned to know that this would be the ultimate outcome for these children. SoI fully endorse the recommendation of the committee about the need for early intervention strategies, and I endorse the response from the government in this area. The other very important area that I think we should spend a couple of minutes on is the types of violence. If one looks at the media representations, one tends to see the more overt type ()f bullying. But, as the previous speaker said, actual, overt. physical violence-the 'putting kids' heads down the toilets' type of harassment, which still happens-is less rare than other forms of bullying. However, the other forms of bullying are particularly destructive to the developing selfesteem of young people. I quote from page 7. It says: The Committee was told that one of the biggest unrecognised aspects of violence in schools was gender harassment. As a component of violence, it was widespread in schools and was largely unrecognised as a violent act. One survey found that, as part of their day to day routine, girls in co-educational classrooms and school yards suffered sex-based harassment from boys and sometimes teachers. The Committee was also advised that physical violence amongst girls was more likely to occur than it was in the past. That was mentioned by the previous speaker. It goes on to say: Harassment and violence is also directed towards gay, lesbian and bisexual students. On that point, I want to quote from an article headed 'Homophobia starts at school, let's stop it here' in the Australian of 1 March-just yesterday, in fact-which gives an account of a high school assembly on 1 August last year where it was suggested that an absent student was gay. When this student attempted to have redress for this accusation, and the resulting hostility MC 1492 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 March 1995 and isolation, he got no support at all. I gather this case is now subject to some further investigation. This is one of the newer types of harassment-attempting to pigeonhole all the students in terms of their gender orientation. But it is absolutely inappropriate, whether it be in grade two or in grade eight or nine, where I believe it reaches its zenith. It is a way of isolating and imposing a power differential. Often that involves a peer group-there is an in-group and an out-group, whether it is the cool group and the not-so-cool group or some other group. But to raise suggestions that someone is not in the mainstream of heterosexual orientation is very distressing to many students who, of course, have not really developed a clear sexual orientation. It is very important that those kinds of issues are addressed and students learn to understand the type of process in which they are all unconsciously involved. I have certainly seen this operating in schools in my electorate. Racism and talking about different ethnic backgrounds is very important. The other issue that is part of this is where students are different and I suspect this is what the previous speaker was mentioning. Gender harassment is not all about violence from one sex to the other, although the evidence indicates that it is males who primarily are the perpetrators. However, it is about students who are different, and one of the things that all schools must address is the importance of allowing people to be themselves. Not everybody is going to be the best cricketer, the best netball player, the most beautiful, most Elle look-alike girl in the school, or the person who looks like whoever the male role models are at the moment-probably Shane Warne or someone. thing is that, across the spectrum, children are as individual as, dare I say, my colleagues in this parliament-and most of us would not make it onto the big screen. I believe it is a very important part of the whole school approach to allow boys to be more feminine and more interested in quieter pursuits, to allow girls to be more assertive and interested in sport and computers, to allow variation and to help students and teachers value that individual difference in people. Teaching students assertive techniques and to be constructively assertive, rather than aggressive, is very important. But clarifying communication is also very important. To return to the gender violence issue, the other part of that that we have to address is the structural inequality in many schools. As the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training said on page 14 of its report on violence in Australian schools: The committee understands that while eighty per cent of teachers in primary schools are women, only twenty to thirty per cent are principals. So already there are a number of power differentials that provide role models for the students. We have to get away from what constitutes masculinity and femininity. I believe' it is an excellent report and I certainly applaud the government's response. That response mentions many of the government's current initiatives that will assist the provision of a much more effective, whole of school approach. For example, on page 13, the Commonwealth reminds us that: Funding totalled about $3 billion in 1993: $1.29 billion supported government schools; $1.59 billion supported non-government schools and $64 million was provided jointly in the two sectors.

speaker: Ms Henzell
theText: Well, if it is the Parliamentary Secretary, I do not mind. But the importantThursday, 2 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1493 Programs like the national domestic violence education program, the national prevention strategy for child abuse and neglect,' which is very important, and the task force on gender equity are all being supported by the Commonwealth. Obviously, once again, cooperation from state governments will be required. Issues such as literacy have been responded to. The committee has made a very positive contribution and I am delighted to see that the government is responding very significantly. MightI say in the last few seconds available to me that my own daughter has won an award to present a film which will go to the issue of violence in families, so I am hoping that her role will make a small contribution. member for La Trobe( Mr Charles). Having heard the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell), I am sure there are a lot of people oil both sides of the chamber who have·dealt with school violence and its results. The member for Capricornia, of course, is a former social worker. I am sure that she has seen that for herself. I will not take much time from the comments I am just about to make but-with all due respect to you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I find it quite extraordinary that we are addressing a report on violence in Australian schools which is of the utmost importance to parents right throughout Australia in what I consider the Clayton's chamber. My views on the necessity for this chamber are well known. I think it is a disgrace that we are not debating this downstairs. Again, I hasten to add, that is said with no disrespect intended to you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am grateful for the opportunity to say a few words before the Main Committee as we take note of the government response to the report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, Sticks and stones, on the issue of violence in Australian schools. The issue of school violence is justifiably of great concern to many in the community. As a parent, I do not think it is too much to expect my children to feel safe and secure when I leave them at school in the morning. I would also expect that my children would learn both respect and responsibility for their fellow students. I think this is an expectation shared by all parents but, regrettably, for some it is not a reality. A recent MBF survey conducted in New South Wales found that a vast majority of primary school children starting high school feared initiation ceremonies and bullying by older students. This fear is real; this fear is genuine. Ms Victoria King, an education consultant from Victoria, states quite correctly that students had limited-what she called-coping skills to deal with being put down or to deal with conflict and bullying. It is these limited coping abilities which result in violence in schools having such a detrimental effect on the victims. Research conducted in the ACT suggested that nearly a quarter of children were likely to be physically or verbally harassed. However, as bUllying rarely occurs in front of an adult witness, it is quite possible that this figure could be higher. I am pleased to say that many states and territories have already recognised the seriousness of this problem and are putting in place strategies to combat it. For example, the ACT education department will move this year to implement an across-the-board policy on school bullying and similar moves are under way in other states. . In Queensland, the government has instigated a school based program called 'Enough's enough'. It is based on the findings of a study which found boys verbally attacked girls on the basis of their sex and boys also suffered similar attacks from other boys if they were seen as too feminine. Indeed, the member for Capricornia has raised an issue that has come to light in the last week.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Ronaldson (Ballarat) (10.31 Am.}
theText: -I support the comments made by the honourableMC 1494 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 March 1995 We all know how.cruel children can be. Unfortunately, what is now called abuse will possibly always be a part of growing up. But what starts out as children acting as children always have, and possibly always will, can become very serious and a cause of great concern for both the children themselves and their. parents. I recently received a letter from a constituent which really brought home to me what we are talking about in this chamber today, I would like to read a section of this letter because I believe that it provides us with an opportunity to focus on the real life consequences of bullying. The names, of course, have been changed. The letter reads: I am writing on behalf of my daughter Jane ... My daughter was descending the stairs during her practical cooking class to do an assignment outside. She was accompanied by Lucy also in that class. The other girls had gone ahead a bit earlier. Lucy was on Jane's right and just after starting down the stairs Lucy put her leg out and tripped Jane. Jane fell between 4-8 stairs before stopping. Lucy stopped for a few seconds, saw a graze on Jane's right wrist then sniggered and continued on down the stairs and out to the other girls. As Jane fell she twisted around catching and ripping a hole in her top from a piece of wirestickirig out from the banister. She hit her head, right shoulder, right elbow, left knee and landed on the back of her right hand, not the palm ... We wentto the hospital for a bone scan. There is 'uptake' to the right hand and wrist and we were informed that she needed extensive physiotherapy and must see an Orthopaedic Surgeon for follow up treatment and another bone scan. While waiting at the bus stop to go to the hospital Jane was harassed by other students at the college who. called her a 'snob' sarcastically mocking her injury and how it occurred. We took Jane to the College to take back the homework she had managed to do, when one of the girls at the College advised Jane not to walk down any dark alleys as, in her words, she might get 'egged'. We are a low income family and we cannot meet the expenses for the physiotherapist or Orthopaedic Surgeon. I realise that this appears to be a silly scrabble between teenagers but my daughter has been injured. It may come as a surprise to many in this chamber that this incident occurred between 17-yearold girls, people on the verge of being treated as adults. Action following the Sticks and stones report should aim to give hope to the Janes across Australia, and to not allow such incidents to occur. I believe the main report makes a valuable contribution to a debate that involves schools, parents, teachers and state education departments throughout the country. The coalition enthusiastically embraces the view of the committee that Australia's schools must provide a safe environment where teachers and students alike can learn; work, play and interact free from fear and abuse. The coalition also supports the committee's finding that it is the right combination of action at the school level that can have the most effective impact on addressing violence in our schools. What the committee's findings show is that strong leadership provided by the principal combined with the teachers working together on the basis of a whole school approach in addressing school violence have proven to be the most effective way of achieving changes in student behaviour. Critical in ensuring such positive changes in student behaviollor is maximum involvement by parents and students. Such programs are already successfully operating across Australia, and I commend the report for acknowledging the role they.play. While this report has my support, some comment needs to be made about certain aspects of the government's response, which again shows the extent to which this government has become glass jawed. Lately it seems that When faced with the slightest bit of criticism about its performance the government reels back and resorts to half truths and distortion of the factsThe government and the minister have clearly been stung by the report's findings and this is clearly evidenced by the contents of the response which is before the chamber today. Thursday, 2 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1495 The first 12 pages of the response are the standard reply that the coalition and the community have come to expect: nothing new, just your typical Labor rhetoric which will result in little or no action. The only proviso I place on that statement is that with an election due the government may act---or, more likely, appear to act-for the most cynical of purposes and that is its re-election. The remaining 21 pages of the document are committed to the government indulging itself in self-glorification. No matter how long the bow is drawn it has fallen over itself to explain ways in which it has allegedly supported or addressed issues raised by the Sticks and stones report. And no stone is left unturned. All this, however, is a rather pathetic attempt to deflect some of the criticisms and conclusions which the committee has drawn. Labor falsely prides itself on being able to lead the country. Leadership is about being able to take on board criticism and learn from it; it is not about indulging in an orgy of self-glorification every time someone suggests ways in which issues could be better handled. The committee reached a very understandable conclusion, and that is that school violence is the end result of a number of factors. The committee has identified family breakdown, illiteracy, violent movies and television as just three of many factors which contribute to violence in schools. I read with interest in the government's response that it claims: . . . more details about the funding arrangements for improving government services to families are given in section 4. But nowhere in section 4 do we find details of Labor's true commitment---or, more truthfully put, its lack of commitment-to families. The promised tax cuts, which were to be l-a-w, turned out to be a l-i-e. Or what about the taxation and family payments system, which is biased against families, giving too little recognition to the expense of bringing up children? Perhaps the government could have mentioned that over 800,000 dependants are in families where no parent has a job, or the widening gap between rich and poor with 78 per cent of those in poverty being family members and 64 per cent of these being in families with children. Again, the government failed to mention the derailed child-care system which in September 1993 saw 214,000 women claiming that the absence of child-care options was the main reason they were not actively looking for work, with 26 per cent of women identifying lack of child-care options as their major career barrier. Mr Deputy Speaker, it might seem to be drawing a long bow to discuss these matters, but when you look at the government's response you will see the long bow that the government has drawn to justify its lack of action. Perhaps the government could have finally mentioned how it has relied on interest rates to squeeze families financially, by constantly lifting home mortgage rates and, even as we speak, keeping families in doubt as to whether they will be undergoing further. interest rate rises or even tax rises. None of this, unfortunately, is mentioned. Neither is the fact that a recent, independent report showed that some 30,000 secondary school students become homeless over a year. Instead, the government has devoted 21 pages to: The following national policy initiatives and programs, in which the Commonwealth plays a major role ... provide structures and support for schools and systems ... That is, families. Let me turn to the issue of literacy. The committee concluded, and I quote, that: The Committee supports the views of principals and teachers that there is a link between student behaviour and poor literacy. MC 1496 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday,2 March 1995 The committee goes further, to recommend that a concerted literacy program would lead to reduced levels of anti-social behaviour in schools. The true extent of literacy in this country was revealed by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training( Mr Free) in an. interview on SBS World News on 18 January this year. The minister was asked what the current state of our literacy was. He replied, 'We're not sure.' The minister says 'not sure', despite the schools council report of December 1994 showing that up to 25 per cent of Australian school children are battling literacy problems, despite the International Literacy Year in 1990, the International Literacy Day on 8 September 1990, The literacy challenge: strategies/or early intervention/or literacy and learning/or Australian children of December 1992, early literacy programs, adult literacy programs, the 1991 Australian language and literacy policy, the 'Book it' program of 1990 and the literacy awards in 1992. After all this, the minister says, ' We're not too sure about the state of our literacy.' It would appear that the government is somewhat confused by the relationship that the committee says exists between literacy and school violence. Remember the committee explicitly stated that: The committee supports the views of principals and teachersthatthere is a link between student behaviour and poor literacy. However, to quote from the response: The Government believes that the causes of violence in schools are many and varied, and notes that any causal link between literacy and violence is not established. Not only does the government not agree with the views of principals and teachers, but, it would appear, the government disagrees with the committee and, therefore, does not agree with its own members. The fallacy of the government's position on this issue is no more clearly shown than on page 34 of the response, where it proudly asserts that the students at risk-Star-program funds a range of school based projects which may assist in addressing violence in schools. Guess what one of the programs is which Star suggests will address violence in high schools? You guessed it, Mr Deputy Speaker: it is basic literacy. The government has fallen in a heap on the issue of literacy. When trying to justify its failings, it does little more than expose its total confusion and ineptness on this issue. There are many examples of the government's attempting to deflect conclusions made by the committee. So insecure is the government on this issue that it has deliberately tried to avoid the committee's findings. The report identifies increasing retention rates and changes in student population as factors that encourage violence in schools. I stress that the committee did not state that these factors cause school violence, but merely stated that they encourage violence in schools. However, so stung is the government by this claim that the government response states: The assertion is made in the context of assumptions about causesI repeat' causes'which have not been supported by credible research. That comment demeans the extensive and far-reaching results of the committee inquiry, pays no regard to the committee's very exhaustive investigation into violence in schools, and is a totally unwarranted attack on the members of that committee. Thursday, 2 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1497 Let me say that the standard, conclusions and recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education .and Training are in stark contrast to this pitiful reply made by the government. Where the committee has sought answers, the government has sought· excuses. Where the committee has sought to place responsibility, the government has run a mile from it. Where the committee has sought team work, cooperation and facts, the government has sought to demean the committee's work and to demean the outcome of the committee's exhaustive inquiries. When taking note of the paper, let the House take note of the quality of the report-a quality that stands in stark contrast to the qualities of the government's response. I think, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the government's response should be called' 12 pages of platitudes and 21 pages of excuses'. Ballarat( Mr Ronaldson) that there are only two governments in this country that have shown a commitment to education: one is Queensland, and the other is the Commonwealth. Every other state government in this country that is largely responsible for children of this age group has denied funding and reduced funding. In fact, Mr Kennett in Victoria has reduced funding for education by some half a billion dollars. The member for Wakefield ( Mr Andrew) will know that his Premier has reduced funding to education in South Australia by $40 million, with more to come. The member for Franklin( Mr Quick), the colleague behind me, knows that the Liberal government in Tasmania has reduced funding. Western Australia has reduced funding. Let us not get facts in the way of a good story! In taking note of the government's response to the report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training called Sticks and stones: report on violence in Australian schools, I would like to comment on four of the seven major matters raised. They are positive parenting, best practice in schools, data collection in schools and early intervention. Parents are key partners in education. Their role as primary educators of their children and their continuing support during the years of schooling are critical elements in ensuring successful outcomes from their children's education. Along with those statements, the Commonwealth· government recognises the pivotal role that parents need to play in strategies to tackle violence in schools. No-one in this chamber would disagree with the sentiments of the government's response, but what exactly is positive parenting? What are the fundamental and essential attributes? I spent 25 years of my working life as a teacher and a principal of primary-aged children and obviously I came across children predisposed to verbal and physical violence and antisocial behaviour. In dealing with those children and their parents, I learned by experience and analysis of what happened that certain characteristics were always common. The child always had a parent or parents whose own behaviour and relationship with the child were dominated by inconsistency. Let me try and explain with a few real life examples. I remember a child whose parents were obviously part of the alternative society. In that family there were very few, if any, rules other. than that, if a problem arose, a situational negotiation took place to attempt to solve it. The parents' dress and behaviour was often remarked on in the community as outlandish, and I am sure that the parents in question enjoyed their shock on the local community with quiet humour. However, the point I want to make is that the child was very well adjusted indeed, and in fact was a real asset to the school community; From the child's point ofview---:-and that is often overlooked-his parents, in their behaviour and relationship with him, were totally consistent, fair, predictable, and
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Sawford (Port Adelaide) (10.45 A.m.)
theText: I think I should remind the member forMC 1498 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 March 1995 providing the child with the necessary security and certainty in dealing with everyday situations, without the need to resort to verbal or physical violence. I also experienced examples at the other end of the spectrum from that laissez-faire example. Another child I remember had parents who had a rule for everything and a punishment that, without exception, was always carried out if a rule was transgressed. It was a very strict household but, as with the laissez-faire family, I would not try to emulate it myself. Nevertheless, the child from that strict family was extremely well adjusted. Again, from the child's point of view, his parents were fair, consistent and totally predictable-even if I thought they were too strict. In other words, whether parents were strict or laissez-faire or somewhere in between did not seem to matter, as long as the relationship was consistent between the parents and the child. It also did not seem to matter-and this goes against a lot of the research-whether the child was a girl or a boy. Gender issues did not matter. Socioeconomic status did not seem to matter. Religious, cultural or racial status did not matter. By contrast, and without exception, all children I have dealt with who were predisposed to violence had a parent or parents unable or unwilling to develop a relationship with their offspring that could be described as consistent. The result was children whose sense of selfworth was confused, diminished, or even inflated; whose relationships with other children and adults were marked with conflict; and whose skills in dealing with often everyday trivial circumstances were minimal. The point I make about positive parenting, and I much prefer. to call it 'consistent' parenting, is that the views of children themselves must be valued and acknowledged. AlthoughI wel<;ome the government's response on initiatives to ask parent groups to provide advice about the role schools should play in promoting positive parenting, and I acknowledge the positive parenting approach underpinning the national prevention strategy for child abuse and neglect-as well as a major community education campaign and an independent assessment of all major parenting programs currently delivered in Australia-that information will never be complete or effectual, and will provide a poor framework for policy if the views of children themselves are ignored. All the partners in the relationships between children and adults need to be considered, and to leave children out of the equation is totally unacceptable and downright foolhardy. There are many schools in this country which, in different ways, exemplify outstanding behaviour and school management-and then there are others in both the private and the public system. I find it very hard to accept that, after well over 100 years of compulsory education in Australia, some things have simply not changed in many primary schools. The most remarkable aspect is the basic structure used in these schools: that is, one teacher is largely responsible for the school education of a class of around 30 children for 10 months of the year. That structure is repeated year in, yearout, for seven years. It is too bad if there is a relationship breakdown or indifference between pupil and student; too bad if the teacher has neither the interest nor the skill in the four major curriculum areas of language-including a foreign language-mathematics, environmental studies and the expressive arts and physical education. In 25 years I have never seen a teacher expert in all of those areas; the expectation that any teacher could be is totally unrealistic. Thirty years ago, some primary teachers could get away with basic English, simple arithmetic, a bit of history and geography, music lessons from a radio broadcast, a pastel lesson Thursday, 2 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1499 once a week and a game in the park. But that curriculum structure is long gone; it has outlived its usefulness. Today, primary teachers are expected to teach all aspects of language, including a foreign language. They are expected to teach all aspects of mathematics: sets, logic, graphing, basic algebra, geometry and numeration. They are expected to be up to date with computer and information technology. They are expected to teach health and science. They are expected to teach environmental studies. They are expected to be aware of behaviour management, gender issues, sociology, psychology, collaborative learning and to be sensitive to cultural and racial matters. The list goes on and on. education, and there are many other subjects. Teachers are expected to teach art and craft and design; music, including the learning of a musical instrument; dance; gymnastics; and major and minor sports, including personal fitness. The message is clear-it is impossible. Children need to be skilfully exposed to all of that curriculum. No-one would disagree with that contention. The problem is that no one teacher has the interest or the skills to do what is expected. The expectation from the community and government that teachers should do this is patently ridiculous. It is too bad if you are a child with a teacher whose interests and skills differ-you are stuck. Bored and uninterested students are potentially violent and anti-social students. Students unable to succeed in their chosen areas are potentially violent and anti-social students. Students unable to develop a positive relationship with a teacher, because of different interests or personality, are potentially violent and anti-social students. The chief determinant of a successful school will always be a quality education program, enhanced by the principal's leadership, in which a group of teachers-not individuals-with complementary skills and interests are responsible for children: that is, the children in any school year will be exposed to several teachers and not just one. However, with the teacher resources available in most primary schools, that is not possible. In many cases it cannot even be considered. But in the few schools that do expose children to a range of teachers, what do we find? We find that behaviour management is a very minor issue. It does not matter whether they are middle class or working class or top-of-the-range schools. Interested, motivated, happy, enthusiastic students do not become behaviour problems, irrespective of their home circumstances. I am, therefore, very pleased that the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training( Mr Free) has indicated a willingness to investigate the possibility of establishing, in cooperation with state and territory governments-we might remember that these are the people who are largely responsible for the education of these children-and non-government school authorities a best practice award for schools that display leadership. They are out there, but they are seldom acknowledged other than in their local community, and even then sometimes not acknowledged for the right reasons. The third area I would like to address is the matter of data collection in schools. It is extremely important that the Commonwealth support the standing committee proposal for a consistent approach to the collection of accurate data, not only on violence but on a whole range of matters that affect our younger generation. We cannot afford to ignore any more the generation of the future now aged under 12 years. I am very pleased that the minister and the government concur on this matter.

speaker: Mr Sawford
theText: Civics is now being introduced. The member for Wakefield mentions sexMC 1500 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 March 1995 The current data on primary schools in this nation is appalling and it is a very sad indictment of state governments, bureaucracies and the education community in general. All areasuniversities, TAFEs, secondary schools-have appalling leadership when it comes to education, across the whole area. Young children in this nation are served poorly by this nation. What national organisation has successfully looked after the interests of the children under 12? Noone in this chamber could name one, because the answer is 'None.' Yet here we are, in an age of national lobby groups for everything-almost one for ink lovers; you name it, there is a national lobby group. There is basically no effective, successful national lobby group for children between the ages of five and 12. Why are the resources allocated to this age group so much lower than for any other age group in Australia? Why are they so powerless? Why are per capita grants for a 12-year-old in a primary school up to $1,000 lower than for a 12-year-old child in a secondary school? Does something magic occur to children in the Christmas vacation before entry to secondary school? Does paper cost more, do books cost more, do photocopiers cost more? Nonsense, Why are there, for exactly the same number of students, up to half as many teaching staff in a primary school as in a secondary school or TAFE institution? One would think there must be an educational reason for those huge differentials. There is not. The current allocation of educational resources in this nation reflects historical tradition and power. There is very little or no educational merit or rationale whatsoever. It is about power, and these children and their teachers do not have any. That is why they do not have adequate funds. That is what seems to be the continued fate of primary schools in the bringing up of our children. The younger the learner, the more dependent, the more vulnerable, the more precious, and the greater the chance for something to go wrong. The older the learner, the more independent, the more self-reliant, the easier to teach, and the less the chance for something to go wrong. That is not rhetoric. That is facts. Why is not it acted upon? Even if acknowledged, it is acknowledged in a very disingenuous way. Collection of data on children is a sensitive matter and is recognised as such by teacher and parent groups. But this is little excuse for the political naivety of teachers and parents in resisting some forms of data collection and being manipulated, albeit in a subtle way, by bureaucracies to, in reality, sit on their hands and conduct talkfest after talkfest. The 10 or 20 per cent of children who have literacy problems in our schools and their lack of success in school are potentially the angry and violent students of tomorrow. Poor parenting increases the risk dramatically. Poor schooling also increases the risk dramatically. Add a failure by the community and governments to adequately allocate a fair share of resources to children aged five to 12, and this nation has a recipe for a monumental and very expensive problem which is now evident to anyone who cares to observe what happens in schools and the community. Early intervention works. Many members here this morning have mentioned that. It is cheaper than remedial measures. Remedial measures often do not work, and the increasing need for remedial measures in schools is ample evidence of system failure. Early intervention makes good sense, and prevention is cheaper and more effective than cure. (Extension of time granted) I welcome the standing committee's report, and I commend the minister for the government's response in moving the debate onwards; but no-one ought to be deluded. This nation needs Thursday, 2 March 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1501 to acknowledge the needs of young children, and eventually will be forced to do so for a very simple and fundamental reason: that it is in the best interests of this nation, in a very nonforgiving and highly competitive world that will be ever more so in the future. In this opportunity to take note of the report this morning, members of both the opposition and the government have shown that there is a great deal of interest in this; but there has to be a lot more than talk. It is time that a group of people in Australia who have the most minimal resources spent upon them by state and federal governments is recognised, because it is in all of our interests that children get off to a very good start, both socially and academically and in all other ways. That happens in our primary schools and in the relationships between parents and children. They need assistance, and it is time both Commonwealth and state governments, with all the members of this parliament, recognised that. I thank you for the extension of time. this motion that we take note of the report Sticks and stones, done by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, I first congratulate the member for Port Adelaide( Mr Sawford) on the contribution he has made to the debate. I hope he does not regard this remark as in any sense belittling his speech: I think it is a speech that could have been made by members on either side of this committee chamber. some strange reason, because we were not being antagonistic, we in some way belittled the contribution he had made. I would also say that it reflected the professionalism that he brings into this chamber in view of his 25 years of experience in the teaching profession. I was very appreciative of the illustrations he brought from the experiences he had had as an educator. I am not one who has had any professional involvement in education at all. But I have, in common with other people in the chamber, an interest in what education is all about; because I am, in common with most others, a parent. As a parent all too frequently absent from the role that ought to be exercised in the education of children-and that is a frustration we all face as members of the federal parliament-I nonetheless have endeavoured to be familiar with what was happening to my children in schools. I have been advantaged by the fact that my wife was herself, prior to the children arriving, a secondary school teacher, and that she is therefore anxious to ensure that their education is of the highest order. She has always kept me briefed on what she thought were the various strengths and weaknesses of their education and of the schools they were attending. In thumbing through the report Sticks and stones-and I am not on the standing committee, so I was not directly involved in its preparation-what impressed me most was that violence is not a regular feature of Australian school life. That was an observation I expected to be able to make, because my children have not been any more exposed to bullying and violent behaviour than I was 40 years ago, as illustrated by the comments by member for Port Adelaide. In fact, as other members would be aware, the reports of antisocial and violent behaviour in New South Wales schools affected, it was alleged, only 0.04 per cent of students. In the case of ACT schools, in 1991 the number of suspensions was 447 out of 40,000 students, representing 0.01 per cent. My observations are that my children are no more exposed to verbal harassment and physical harassment than I was-and, in fact, probably less so. I think that children have a right, as

theText: And should be, I clearly agree. If there is one thing that has been brought home to me as a parent, it is that the self-esteem of individual children is of fundamental importance. The honourable member for Port Adelaide reinforced this not only with the illustrations he used from his own experience but also with the comments he made as a professional. If people feel they have self-worth and feel they have a contribution to make to society, it is highly unlikely that they will be involved in violent behaviour. I have only one problem with the honourable member for Port Adelaide's comments. He said that interested, motivated, enthusiastic students do not become problems regardless of their home background. I expect he is right; however, very few interested, motivated, enthusiastic students come out of a difficult home background. merely making the observation that it is much easier to be an interested, motivated and enthusiastic student if the parents have already cultivated that sense of enthusiasm at home. I well remember what for me was the most terrorising book I have read. I read it very early in my primary school days, which was probably a mistake. I was amused by one of my colleagues who observed the other day that the best three years of his life had been spent in year one-that was a mischievous remark. I remember that it was not long after I acquired the capacity to read that someone gave me the book Tom Brown's Schooldays. I read it and I was mortified. I feared that I would experience either in the latter part of primary school or in secondary school the sort of bullying that was characterised in the book Tom Brown's Schooldays. I was obviously much too immature to have read the book at the time; it set an artificial scene for me of what secondary school life would be like. For most of us, some sort of verbal harassment and, I suspect, for most of our generation, some physical harassment was a reality of the schools in which we grew up. That did not make it defensible, but it was a reality, and I suspect that exhibits itself less frequently today than it did in my own day. From my experience as a parent, bullying and harassment is less of a feature of all-girls schools than it is of all-boys schools. My children spent their primary school years in public schools. They spent their secondary schooling in private schools, with the exception of one child, who had two years of his secondary schooling in a public school. From my daughter's experience in an all-girls school in Adelaide, it was the best thing we did for her. Her sense of self-esteem was enhanced and there was relatively little physical bullying. Of course, there was some verbal bullying that characterises what we would loosely call-and I use the term advisedly-the 'bitchiness' of an all-girls school environment. On the other hand, my oldest son for the latter part of his secondary schooling went to an all-boys school where bullying was more a part of the scene-and we all know what goes on at all-boys schools. As a result of his experience, we have sent our younger son to a school catering for both sexes. Lest it be thought that I am being critical of the schooling experience of my older son, I should say that, in confronting the headmaster with our decision not to send our younger son there, I was impressed with what had been done in the intervening years by that school community to address the problem of both bullying and verbal abuse.
